Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
>  
>
> [stuff about using source/target neuron ID pairs instead of a 
> connection innovation ID]
>
>
>I think sometimes it may be desirable to assign a different 
>innovation number connecting two of the same nodes.  This goes back 
>to the debate about how long to keep a record of innovation 
>numbers.  In the FAQ I give some reasons I chose to only keep them 
>around for 1 generation.  In your proposed model, this wouldn't be 
>an option.  Also, it's nice to know the order that connections 
>appeared.  If you ever look at a NEAT genome you can tell how often 
>connections are successful and in what order they were put togther 
>by looking at their innovation numbers.  Aside from these concerns, 
>your idea is still doable but you'd lose these capabilities.
>  
>
I kind of like the idea. As a substitute for the loss of history I was 
thinking of storing the generation number at which a connection was created.

Anyway this only relates to connections, maintaining consistent neuron 
IDs seems trickier. When a neuron is added it splits a connection, that 
connection has a source and target neuron, but several other splits 
could have occured in the past between the same two neurons. How do I 
know which neuron my new neuron is equivalent to? Now, if I look through 
a histrory of previous splits as your (Ken) NEAT does and also JOONE I 
can lookup the connection ID. Fine. But when you load in a population 
from file you have lost the history. Something equivalent to the 
hashtable lookup for conenctions would be ideal, but I'm not sure it's 
possible.

Colin.
